page.title: 01Brownsea Island
page.content: Brownsea Island is 500 acres in extent, measuring 1\ miles long by \ mile wide. Together with the smaller island of Furzey it lies at the entrance to the great natural habour of Poole in Dorset. After a chequered history the island now belongs to the National Trust and it is open to the public daily from April to the end of September. Around 100,000 visitors come to Brownsea each year and on the day of our visit (14th July 1985), in rather cloudy weather, 435 people had paid to come ashore including a party of 33 West German students, 16 tourists from Spain and a family of 4 from Bangladesh. Browsea now has a resident{population} of about 30 people most of whom work for the National Trust.
